author: LarsFosdal
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

In PowerShell 7.1.5, with admin right, calling
Set-Service <name> -StartupType AutomaticDelayedStart
does not result in the service getting a change in the startup type.

### Expected behavior

```console
When I visually inspect the service in the Services window, I expected to see the Startup Type listed as "Automatic (Delayed Startup)"
```


### Actual behavior

```console
When I visually inspect the service in the Services window, I see the Startup Type listed as "Automatic"
```


### Error details

```console
No errors returned
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17763
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
I checked with latest 7.2 build and this work well. Do you have permissions to do the operation for _the service_?

Follow works for me:
```powershell
Set-Service AppMgmt -StartupType AutomaticDelayedStart
Set-Service AppMgmt -StartupType Manual
```

comments.author: LarsFosdal
comments.body:
Yes, the executing account has local admin rights and the script runs elevated, and the service is set up to log on as that account.

Can you verify that -StartupType Automatic and AutomaticDelayedStart gives different results in the Services window list?
For me, it appears that both set it to just Automatic.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
> Can you verify that -StartupType Automatic and AutomaticDelayedStart gives different results in the Services window list?

Yes
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22290914/140725564-cda3255e-ef9e-4efc-8de1-15f1370b8c00.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22290914/140725703-31be5d54-2d91-4472-a640-02b7708e2e8d.png)

comments.author: LarsFosdal
comments.body:
Have I left out a possible important detail?  
The service is 32-bit and runs under WOW64.

comments.author: LarsFosdal
comments.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7009177/140727550-232db60d-dd30-43c6-822c-41d6d4e6a754.png)
Note that the delayed start flag has been manually enabled in the GUI.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: PowerShell p/invoke ChangeServiceConfig2W - there are not arguments about Wow64.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
> The service is 32-bit and runs under WOW64.

AFAIK that's not really part of the service configuration and is just what happens when you get the service to start a 32-bit executable. Could you run `sc.exe config MyService start= delayed-auto` and see if you have the same behaviour?

title: Set-Service <name> -StartupType AutomaticDelayedStart sets startup to Automatic
